questions.text: What is the preferred drug for the treatment of an infection caused by the organism whose life cycle is given below?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle of a rhabditiform larva being infective to man via penetration of skin along with the autoinfection cycle is suggestive of Strongyloides stercoralis. The preferred drug for the treatment of an infection by Strongyloides stercoralis is Ivermectin.

Ivermectin given orally for 2 days is considered the treatment of choice for human strongyloidiasis. Extended treatment for at least 14 days or at least a week after parasites have been eradicated is required in case of disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Strongyloides stercoralis has a parasitic cycle and a free-living cycle in soil. Humans are the natural host but morphologically indistinguishable strains may be seen in dogs and cats. Filariform larvae are the infective form and there are two modes of infection: penetration of the skin by 3rd stage filariform larva, and autoinfection (external and internal).

The female worms present in the intestine lay eggs in the mucosa which hatches immediately, releasing the rhabditiform larva. The larva migrates into the lumen of the intestine and passes down to be released in the feces. The rhabditiform larva may change into a filariform larva while passing through the bowel.

The filariform larvae in the bowel do not leave the host and become a source of autoinfection as they penetrate the colonic mucosa or perianal skin. The rhabditiform larvae passed in the feces may undergo two types of development in the soil:

  1. Direct development: The rhabditiform larva molts twice on reaching the soil to become the infective filariform larva. The filariform larva can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation.
  2. Indirect development: The rhabditiform larvae develop into free-living males and females in the soil.

Other options:

Option B: Praziquantel is the drug of choice for the treatment of infections caused by trematodes like Schistosoma, Clonorchis, Opisthorchis, Fasciolopis, Paragonimus, and cestodes like Hymenolepis, Diphyllobothrium, and Taenia.

Option C: A 3-day course of Albendazole (400 mg daily) can be used for the treatment of strongyloidiasis but is less efficacious than Ivermectin. Albendazole is the drug of choice for infections caused by nematodes like Ascaris and Trichura, and in cases of neurocysticercosis caused by larval forms of Taenia solium, a cestode.

Option D: Diethylcarbamazine is used in the treatment of lymphatic filariasis and loasis.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Cestode
Diphyllobothrium latum Plerocercoid larva Eggs or segments of the tapeworm
Taenia saginata Cysticercus bovis Egg
Taenia solium Cysticercus cellulosae Egg (for intestinal taeniasis ) / cysticercus cellulosae larva (for cysticercosis)
Echinococcus granulosus Egg Protoscolices and brood capsules
Hymenolepsis nana Egg Egg
Trematode

Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
Nematode

Ancylostoma duodenale

Necator americanus

Strongyloides stercoralis Filariform larva Rhabditiform larva
Trichuris trichuria Embryonated Egg Unembryonated Egg
Enterobius vermicularis Egg Eggs from perianal skin
Filarial nematodes Third stage Filarial larva (L3) Microfilariae

questions.text: The life cycle of a parasite is given below. Which of the following is true regarding the eggs produced by this parasite?

choices.text: Non-bile stained, does not float in saturated salt solution
Bile stained, floats in saturated salt solution
Non-bile stained, floats in saturated salt solution
Bile stained, does not float in saturated salt solution

questions.solution:
The given image depicts the life cycle of Hymenolepis nana. The eggs of H.nana are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution.

The eggs of Hymenolepis nana are about 30-40 μm in size and roughly spherical or ovoid in shape. It is covered by a thin colorless outer membrane with the hexacanth oncosphere enclosed inside the inner embryophore. Yolk granules and 4-8 thread-like polar filaments, arising from two knobs on the embryophore, are present in the space between the two membranes.

The eggs are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. The eggs cannot survive for more than 10 days in the external environment and are immediately infective after release. The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm. Humans are the definitive host. It has no intermediate host. It occurs more commonly in children and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The egg attaches to the intestine and develops into the larva and adult worm. The adult worm resides in the small intestine.  

Patients are usually asymptomatic. But in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response.

It can also cause autoinfection. Internal autoinfection occurs when the eggs are released in the intestine and hatch there. External autoinfection occurs through the ingestion of the eggs by the fecal-oral route. They hatch in the small intestine to release the hexacanth embryo which penetrates the intestinal villus resulting in autoinfection.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for infection with H. nana. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

questions.text: What is the most common cancer associated with the organism whose life cycle is given below?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle with free-swimming cercariae in water and metacercariae in the flesh of freshwater fish is suggestive of liver flukes- either Clonorchis or Opisthorchis. Both Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini are associated with an increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma, in China and Thailand respectively.

Clonorchis, also known as Chinese or Oriental liver fluke, is known to cause disease in Japan, Korea, Taiwan, China, and Vietnam. Similarly, infection with Opisthorchis viverrini is commonly seen in Thailand. 

Both Clonorchis and Opisthorchis have the same life cycle. Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing encysted larvae (metacercariae). The immature flukes after excystation in the duodenum enter the biliary ducts and differentiate into adults.

The hermaphroditic adults produce eggs that are excreted in the feces. Upon reaching freshwater the eggs are ingested by snails, which are the first intermediate hosts. The eggs hatch within the gut and differentiate first into larvae (sporocyst and redia stages) and then into many free-swimming cercariae. Cercariae encyst to form metacercariae under the scales of certain freshwater fish (second intermediate host) which are then ingested by humans.

In humans, the metacercariae excyst in the duodenum and the adolescaria travel to the common bile duct and then to the distal bile capillaries where they transform into adult worms. The adult worms can cause obstruction of the common bile duct and lead to cholangitis. Most people are asymptomatic. Others may show fever, epigastric pain, jaundice, and progressive liver enlargement. 

Stool microscopy demonstrates eggs that do not float in saturated saline. Praziquantel is the drug of choice for the treatment of this condition.

Other options:

Option A. Gastric carcinoma - Helicobacter pylori infection is a major risk factor for the development of gastric carcinoma.

Option B. Bladder carcinoma - The vesical blood fluke Schistosoma haematobium primarily infects the urinary bladder and increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma is associated with hepatitis B/C infection.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old female presents with painless haematuria. She has a travel history to Egypt a few weeks back. Urine microscopy revealed the following structure. Which of the following stage is not seen in the life cycle of the causative organism?
  1. Cercaria 
  2. Metacercaria 
  3. Miracidia
  4. Redia
questions.solution:
Eggs with a terminal spine and a history of painless hematuria are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma haematobium. Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes.  Metacercaria and redia are seen in trematodes such as Fasciola hepatica, Fasciola buski, Clonorchis sinensis.

Schistosoma haematobium is characterized by ovoid non-operculated eggs with a brownish-yellow transparent shell and a characteristic terminal spine at one of the poles.

Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis. The adult worms live in the veins of the urinary bladder.

Cercaria larva are the infective form of schistosomes. Cercaria infects man by penetrating the skin which can lead to intense irritation and skin rash at the site of cercarial penetration (known as swimmer's itch).

After penetrating the skin, the cercariae lose their tails and become schistosomulae which travel through peripheral venules to the systemic circulation, to the inferior mesenteric veins, finally reaching the vesical and pelvic venous plexuses, where they mature and lay eggs. The eggs that are passed in urine are embryonated and hatch in water under suitable conditions to release the free-living ciliated miracidia.

Miracidia penetrates into the tissues of the snail and reaches its liver. Inside the snail, first and second-generation sporocyst stages are seen. Large numbers of cercariae are produced by asexual reproduction within the second-generation sporocysts and are released into the water. Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

The following are the unique features distinguishing schistosomes from other trematodes:

  • Only one intermediate host
  • They produce non- operculated eggs.
  • They have no redia stage in larval development
  • Mode of infection is by penetration of intact skin with the help of forked tails of cercariae

NOTE: 

Infective forms of most trematodes (Eg. Fasciola hepatica, Fasciola buski, Clonorchis sinensis) to humans are metacercaria larva.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine on their eggs as follows.

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: The image given below depicts the life cycle of _______.
questions.solution:
The image given above depicts the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides.

It is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human faeces having eggs of Ascaris that contain the infective rhabditiform larva. Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host.

The life cycle is as follows:

  • Adult worms live in the lumen of the small intestine. A female produces eggs which are passed with the faeces. 
  • Unfertilized eggs may be ingested but are not infective.
  • Larvae develop infectivity within fertile eggs in 10-40 days. It depends on the environmental conditions (optimum: moist, warm, shaded soil).
  • After infective eggs are swallowed, the larvae hatch.
  • The larvae invade the intestinal mucosa and are carried through the portal system, then systemic circulation to the lungs.
  • The larvae mature further in the lungs (10 to 14 days), penetrate the alveolar walls, ascend the bronchial tree to the throat, and are swallowed.
  • Upon reaching the small intestine, they develop into adult worms. Between 2 and 3 months are required from ingestion of the infective eggs to oviposition by the adult female. Adult worms can live for 1 to 2 years.

Adult worms can be occasionally detected in the stool or sputum of the patient. A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstration of eggs in faeces. Fertilized eggs are always bile stained. 

Effective and safe drugs for the treatment of ascariasis are Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg once, Albendazole 400 mg once, Mebendazole 100 mg twice daily for 3 days, Ivermectin 150-200 mcg/kg once.

The image below shows the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides: 

Other options:

Option B. Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke - trematode) infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab/ crayfish containing metacercariae. It causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis (coughing and hemoptysis).

  • Definitive host: Man, cats, tigers, leopards, foxes, dogs, pigs, beavers, and domestic animals.
  • First intermediate host: Freshwater snail.
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The given image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani:

Option C. Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke (trematode) that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica:

Option D. Brugia malayi is a nematode that also causes filariasis in man. The intermediate hosts of Brugia are vectors of genera Mansonia, Anopheles, and Aedes. In India, the main vectors are Mansonia annulifera and Mansonia uniformis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. It is given orally in a dose of 6 mg/kg body weight daily, for a period of 12 days.

Life cycle of Brugia malayi:

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue,  breathlessness, paresthesias, and a  stomping gait. The peripheral blood smear shows a megaloblastic picture. The lifecycle of the causative organism is shown below. Which of the following can be responsible for this deficiency?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of Vitamin B12 deficiency which can be caused by the broad or fish tapeworm - Diphyllobothrium latum.

Diphyllobothrium latum infection usually causes vitamin B12 deficiency by absorbing large quantities of vitamin B12 and interfering with the ileal absorption thereby making it unavailable to the host.

The first intermediate host is a freshwater crustacean, while the second intermediate host is freshwater fish. The definitive hosts are man, dog, and cat. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called oncosphere.

The pernicious anaemia caused by the infection is called bothriocephalus anaemia.

Treatment is praziquantel in a single dose of 10 mg/kg. In severe B12 deficiency, parenteral vitamin B12 should be given. 

Other options:

Beef tapeworm (option A) is Taenia saginata and pork tapeworm (option B) is Taenia solium. Both of them live in the adult small intestine. Man is the definitive host for both species while cattle and pigs are the intermediate hosts for T. saginata and T. solium respectively. 

Manifestations include:

  • Intestinal taeniasis is characterised by vague abdominal discomfort, indigestion, nausea, diarrhoea and weight loss. 
  • Cysticercosis in subcutaneous tissues (nodules), muscles (acute myositis), and brain (neurocysticercosis)

The below image shows the life cycle of T. saginata and T. solium

 

Dwarf tapeworm (option C) is the common name for Hymenolepis Nana which manifests as nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and irritability in severe cases and the life cycle is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A child presents with chronic diarrhea,  weight loss, and fatigue. On examination, he was pale, with decreased height for age score. The life cycle of the causative organism is given in the image below. Which of the following is not a known complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
The life cycle given above denoting adult worms in the large intestine with them having a slender anterior end and a 'whip-like' thick posterior end is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm). Focal seizures or cerebral involvement is not a known complication of trichuriasis. 

Trichuriasis is caused by T. trichiura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon.

Clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental defects. The disease may result either due to the mechanical effect of the worms or an allergic reaction to the parasite.

Trichuris trichiura causes rectal prolapse in children (characteristic feature) because the rectum loses its internal support as the worms bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles; also, there is rectal edema because of the infection. All these factors finally lead to rectal prolapse. In heavy infection with T. trichiura, sigmoidoscopy may show white bodies of worms hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so-called coconut cake rectum. 

Other complications include dysentery, diarrhea, tenesmus, iron deficiency anemia, and poor growth. The poor growth is typically secondary to poor nutrition and consequently causes cognitive delay.

Fecal smears show a barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura. The eggs of T. trichiura do not have a terminal spine. They are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. They get bile-stained and float in the saturated salt solution. An image showing the egg of trichuris is given below.

 

Albendazole 400 mg orally for 3 days is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who recently visited a forest reserve in Karnataka presented with sudden onset of headache, myalgia, fever, and severe prostration. He was diagnosed to have Kyasanur Forest disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the disease?

choices.text: It is caused by a virus of Flaviviridae family.
It is a transmitted by Haemaphysalis spinigera.
Dead monkeys serve as the amplifier of infection.
The disease spreads on contact with an infected patient.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Kyasanur Forest disease (KFD) is that the disease spreads on contact with an infected patient. No person-to-person transmission is described in KFD. 

Kyasanur forest disease is an arboviral infection caused by Kyasanur forest disease virus (KFDV), a member of the virus family Flaviviridae. It is transmitted by the bite of hard ticks, Haemaphysalis spinigera being the principal vector, which also acts as a reservoir. It was endemic to the forests of Karnataka but now has also been detected in neighboring states of Tamil Nadu and Kerala.

Transmission to humans usually occurs after a tick bite or contact with an infected animal (sick or recently dead monkey). Monkeys act as amplifier hosts. Forest birds and small mammals are the reservoir hosts.

The clinical features include constitutional symptoms like fever, headache, conjunctivitis, myalgia, hemorrhagic symptoms, and severe prostration. The diagnosis is established via PCR, virus isolation from blood, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent serologic assay.

A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.

The ecological cycle of kyasanur forest disease is given below.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis
Culex mosquito Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis
Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya
Housefly Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar(Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness(African Trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus(Murine Typhus), hymenolepis diminuta
Black fly(Simulium) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug(Kissing bug/triatominae) Chagas disease(American Trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well)
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea)  Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the given life cycle:
questions.solution:
The life cycle depicted in the above image is of Dracunculus medinensis (Guinea worm).

Humans are the definitive host. They get infected by drinking unfiltered water containing infected cyclops. Larvae come out once cyclops are killed in the stomach and penetrate the wall of the duodenum. They reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues and develop into adults.

The fertilized female worm grows and migrates within the connective tissues. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water like the leg (most common). Here, the gravid female worm secretes a toxin that causes a blister formation. The blister ruptures discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous L1 stage larvae.

The larvae survive for about a week in water. They are swallowed by the intermediate host- freshwater cyclops. The larvae penetrate the gut wall of the cyclops and develop into the infective third-stage larvae. The lifecycle continues when humans drink water containing infective cyclops.

Other options:

Option A: Wuchereria bancrofti passes its life cycle partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

 

 

Option B: The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host.

 

Option C:  Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host, and in mango flies/day-biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors.

questions.text: A young rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, and vomiting. He is also found to have nuchal rigidity and signs of raised intracranial pressure. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Pond herons can act as hosts

questions.solution:
The rice farmer presenting with features of acute encephalitis is likely to have Japanese encephalitis. Man is the incidental dead-end host.

The image shows the Culex mosquito. It can be identified by the presence of unspotted wings, hunched back, and the absence of stripes.  The Culex mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically C. tritaeniorhynchus and C. vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds (pond herons, cattle egret). Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule. 

The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus is shown below:

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following stages of Entamoeba histolytica is considered as an infective form?
questions.solution:
Mature quadrinulceate cyst is considered as the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

The cysts are present only in the lumen of the colon and in formed feces. They initially contain a glycogen vacuole and chromatoid bodies (masses of ribonucleoprotein) with characteristic rounded ends. Nuclear division occurs within the cyst and results in a mature quadrinucleated cyst which has 4 nuclei. The chromatid bodies and glycogen vacuoles disappear.

Other options:

They include various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica

Trophozoite:

  • The trophozoite is the vegetative or growing stage of the parasite.
  • It is found only in tissues
  • The cytoplasm has two zones, a hyaline outer margin and a granular inner region that may contain red blood cells (pathognomic)
  • Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility
  • Nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance.

Precystic stage:

  • This is formed when the trophozoid extrudes its food vacuoles and becomes round or oval, just before encystment.
  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to further become a cyst

Metacystic trophozoites:

  • This is formed after excystation of the mature cyst once it reaches the intestine. 
  • Initially, the cytoplasm gets detached from the cyst wall and there is a tear in the cyst wall, through which quadrinucleate amoeba is liberated. This stage is called the metacyst.
  • The nuclei in the metacyst immediately undergo division to form eight nuclei, which get surrounded by their own cytoplasm to become eight small amebulae or metacystic trophozoites.

The octanucleate cyst is seen in the case of Entamoeba coli, which is a non-pathogenic commensal amoeba.

The image below shows various stages in the life cycle of entamoeba histolytica

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought with complaints of diarrhea and blood loss to the outpatient department. A stool examination showed  Ancylostoma dudoenale.  All of the given statements regarding Ancylostoma dudoenale are true except:

choices.text: Eggs are shed in faeces of an infected individual
Man and soil are known reservoirs
It can enter the human body through penetration of skin
Immediate source of infection is soil

questions.solution:
The given scenario of diarrhea, blood loss, and stool examination showing the presence of Ancylostoma dudoenale is suggestive of hookworm infection. Man is the only known reservoir of this condition. 

A reservoir is any person, animal, arthropod, plant, soil, or substance in which an infectious agent can live, multiply, and is transmissible to the susceptible host. 

The two main nematodes causing hookworm infection in humans are  Ancylostoma dudoenale and Necator americanus. The affected individuals can present with blood loss, diarrhea, and iron deficiency anemia. The adult hookworms reside in the small intestine (mainly jejunum) and are attached to the villi. The female worm can lay thousands of eggs which are passed in feces.

Larvae rapidly develop when these eggs land on warm, moist soil, and the egg hatches after 1 to 2 days. This soil contaminated with the infective larvae of this organism is the immediate source of infection. The feces containing the ova of the organisms are considered the infective material. The filariform larvae can enter the human body through penetration of skin or ingestion by mouth. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of Ancylostoma duodenale:

questions.text: Man acts as an intermediate host for all of the following except_____
questions.solution:
Man is the definitive host of Fasciola hepatica. Other definitive hosts are sheep, goats, and cattle. The first intermediate host is the snail. Aquatic plants are the second intermediate host.

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica is given below:

 

Other options:

Option A: The definitive host of Plasmodium ovale is the female anopheles mosquito. The life cycle of Plasmodium species is given below:

Option B: The definitive host of Toxoplasma gondii is the cat. The life cycle of Toxoplasma gondii is given below:

Option D: The definitive host of Babesia microti is the ixodid tick. The life cycle of Babesia microti is given below:

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with excoriation of anal skin was brought by his mother to the pediatric OPD. She states her son scratches his anal area frequently during nighttime. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which of the following is not a feature of the egg of this organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of frequent anal area scratching during nighttime, excoriation of the skin around the anus, and the given life cycle of humans acquiring infection by ingestion of embryonated eggs, which are released by the gravid female over the perianal skin are suggestive of pinworm or Enterobius vermicularis infection. The eggs of pinworms are not bile-stained.

The pinworm eggs have a characteristic plano-convex shape. They are colorless and not bile-stained. They have a thick, double-layered, transparent eggshell. The eggs also float in a saturated salt solution. Inside lies a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo. The eggs are highly infectious, and reinfection should be prevented by regular washing of bed linens, towels, and clothing in hot water.

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. Infection is acquired by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus, crawls around on the perianal and perineal skin, and lays its eggs. This leads to pruritus, and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina, causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

A faecal examination is not useful for diagnosis as the eggs are not usually released in faeces. The eggs can be demonstrated by swabbing the perianal and perineal skin where they are deposited. The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema.

The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) is used to collect specimens for diagnosis. In the NIH swab, the perianal area is swabbed by rolling the cellophane part over it. After detaching the cellophane part, it is spread over a glass slide and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab.

Another method is the scotch tape method, where the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with the sticky side down. Then, a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope.

Treatment involves a single dose of Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg, albendazole 400mg, or mebendazole 100mg. Piperazine is given once daily for a week.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

questions.text: The following image depicts the life cycle of:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus.

The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female black flies, the intermediate host.

During a blood meal, the female blackfly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. It is within the vector that the microfilariae develop into first-stage larvae and subsequently into third-stage infective larvae.

When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

They penetrate into the bite wound and develop into adult worms in the subcutaneous tissues within subcutaneous nodules called onchocercomas or live freely in the tissues.

The adult worm can live in the human host for about 15 years while the microfilariae for about a year.

Other options:

Option A: Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host and in mango flies/day biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors. The microfilariae develop into third-stage larve in the vector. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

Option B: Leishmania donovani completes its life cycle in the female sandfly, the vector and in definitive hosts which include man, dog and other mammals. The promastigote form in the midgut of the sandfly is the infective form. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

Option C: Wucheraria bancrofti passes its life cycle in partly in humans, the definitive host and in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

questions.text: Identify the virus in the transmission cycle shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India)

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option-A: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality. 

The image given below depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus:

 

Option B: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:

 

Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects.

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer is bitten by an insect whose life cycle is as portrayed below. He develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash 2 weeks later. A positive serological diagnosis for this condition is made using agglutination with antigens from which of the following species?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing characteristic eschar with lymphadenopathy and rash, along with the life cycle of a trombiculid mite (which acts as the vector), is suggestive of scrub typhus. It gives a positive Weil-Felix reaction with OX K agglutinins, which are derived from Proteus mirabilis.

Scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus, is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris strains OX19 and OX2 and Proteus mirabilis strain OXK. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and some strains of Proteus.

OXK is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

questions.text: At an outreach program for raising awareness and prevention of endemic diseases, the given life cycle is being used to educate the population. Identify the endemic disease and organism implicated.

choices.text: Hanta virus causing hanta virus pulmonary syndrome

questions.solution:
The life cycle shown in the above image is suggestive of leptospirosis. 

It is caused by contact with the urine or blood of an infected organism. It is a zoonotic disease, with rats being the most well-known reservoirs. 

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are: 

  • Acute leptospiremic phase- organism can be cultured from blood.
  • Resolving immune phase- organism can be cultured from urine.

The stages may not be clinically distinguishable.

Most cases are asymptomatic but a few may present with severe manifestations. Clinical features include: 

  • High-grade fever
  • Hepatic dysfunction 
  • Renal impairment
  • Hemorrhages- gastrointestinal, pulmonary (most common), petechiae and purpura

The severe form is known as Weil's disease, with a triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. 

Treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cough with rusty sputum and fever for the past few weeks. She gives a history of recent travel to Japan and the consumption of raw crabs.  A complete blood count reveals eosinophilia. All of the following are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: It is a food-borne trematode infection.
Eggs are coughed up in sputum.
Embryonated eggs are the infective form.
Praziquantel is the treatment of choice.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke). All the given options are true about this condition, except that embryonated eggs are the infective form.

Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

P. westermani is a trematode. Transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae encyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Treatment: Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The following image shows the life cycle of P. westermani, the oriental lung fluke.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is infected with the organism whose life cycle is as shown below and is diagnosed with visceral larva migrans. The causative organism is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The life cycle portrayed in the image is suggestive of Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) which is an example of an aberrant parasite. It is defined as a parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further.

Parasites can be classified as:

  • Ectoparasites - inhabit only the body surface of the host without penetrating the tissue. The term infestation is often used for parasitization. e.g., lice, ticks, and mites.
  • Endoparasite - lives within the body of the host and causes infection.

Endoparasites are further classified as follows:

  • Obligate parasite - cannot exist without a host. e.g., Toxoplasma gondii and Plasmodium.
  • Facultative parasite - are either parasitic or free-living forms. e.g., Naegleria fowleri.
  • Accidental parasite - parasite that infects an unusual host. e.g., Echinococcus granulosus infects man
  • Aberrant/Wandering parasites - parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further. e.g., Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting humans.

Visceral Larva Migrans :

  • It is a syndrome caused by nematodes that are normally parasitic for nonhuman host species
  • In humans, these nematode larvae do not develop into adult worms, but, instead, migrate through host tissues and elicit eosinophilic inflammation
  • Common causes:
    • Toxocara canis (dog roundworm)- most common
    • Taxocara cati (cat roundworm)
    • Ascaris suum (pig ascaris)
    • Angiosrrongylus cantonensis
    • Gnathostoma spinigerum
    • Anisakis simplex
    • Baylisascaris procyonis
  • Fever, hepatomegaly, pneumonitis, hyperglobulinemia, and pica are the common findings.
  • Patients may develop neurological disturbances (neural larva migrans) and endophthalmitis (ophthalmic larva migrans)
  • Treatment : Diethylcarbamazine (DEC), 100 mg TDS for 3 weeks in an adult, kills the larva and arrests the disease.
